titleStmt.title: The superiority of Emerson's writings
a machine readable transcription

notesStmt.note: The manuscript is bound in a volume, the cover of which dates the manuscript as "c. 1854." This date seems likely. The earliest possible date would be 1847, when Whitman's first known reference to Emerson was published in the December 15, 1847, issue of the Brooklyn Daily Eagle.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: The superiority of Emerson's writing
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original item.

revisionDesc.change: checked, corrected pbs, updated add rend values, corrected handful of typos, added choice tag

body.p:
The superiority of Emerson's writings is in their character—they mean something. He They may be obscure, but they are he is certain.—Any other of the best known American writers has in general a clearer style than he—any one is has more of the received grace and ease—is less questioned and or forbidden than he—makes a better handsomer appearance in the society of the books—sells better—passes for his time more deeper more apparently in the popular understanding; yet there is something in the solitary specimen of New England that outvies them all.—He has what none else have; he does what none else does.—He pierces the crusts that envelope the secrets of life.—He joins on equal terms the great few great sages and original seers.—He represents the freeman, America, the individual. He represents the gentleman.—In Of By nNo teacher or poet, of old times or modern times, has there been made a better report made of manly and womanly qualities, heroism, chastity, temperatence, friendship, fortitude.—None have shown in given more beautiful
portraits accounts of truth and justice.—His words shed light to the best souls; they do not admit of argument. As a sprig from the pine tree or a glimpse any where into the daylight, belittles all artificial flower work and all the painted scenery of theatres, so are live words in a book, toward compared to cunningly composed words.—A Few among men (soon perhaps to become many) will enter on equal terms easily into Emerson's meanings; but to by those few he will be well-beloved.—The flippant writer, the orthodox critic, the great majo numbers of good or indifferent imitators, will not comprehend him; to them he will indeed be a transcendentalist, a writer of sunbeams and moonbeams, a strange anand unapproachable person.
